cards.name: Akroma, Angel of Wrath
cards.text: Flying, first strike, vigilance, trample, haste, protection from black and from red
cards.flavor: "No rest. No mercy. No matter what."

rulings.text: The "legend rule" cares about legendary permanents with the exact same English name. You can control Akroma, Angel of Wrath and Akroma, Angel of Fury at the same time.

cards.originalText:
Flying, first strike, trample, haste, protection from black, protection from red
Attacking doesn't cause Akroma, Angel of Wrath to tap.

cards.name: Akroma's Devoted
cards.text: Cleric creatures have vigilance.
cards.flavor: Akroma asked for only one thing from her troops: unwavering, unconditional loyalty.
cards.originalText: Attacking doesn't cause Clerics to tap.

cards.name: Aven Redeemer
cards.text:
Flying
{T}: Prevent the next 2 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn.
cards.flavor: Redeemers rise with the sun, and the spirits of the people rise with them.
cards.originalText:
Flying
{T}: Prevent the next 2 damage that would be dealt to target creature or player this turn.

cards.name: Beacon of Destiny
cards.text: {T}: The next time a source of your choice would deal damage to you this turn, that damage is dealt to Beacon of Destiny instead.
cards.flavor: "We all borrowed life from the Ancestor to exist in this world. Today, I repay that debt."
cards.originalText: {T}: The next time a source of your choice would deal damage to you this turn, that damage is dealt to Beacon of Destiny instead.

cards.name: Celestial Gatekeeper
cards.text:
Flying
When Celestial Gatekeeper dies, exile it, then return up to two target Bird and/or Cleric permanent cards from your graveyard to the battlefield.

rulings.text: You can choose to target this card as one of the two Bird and/or Cleric cards. If you do, it gets exiled and does not get returned to the battlefield.

cards.originalText:
Flying
When Celestial Gatekeeper is put into a graveyard from play, remove it from the game, then return up to two target Bird and/or Cleric cards from your graveyard to play.

cards.name: Cloudreach Cavalry
cards.text: As long as you control a Bird, Cloudreach Cavalry gets +2/+2 and has flying.
cards.flavor: "It's easy to lose sight of hope until you gaze out from my vantage point."
cards.originalText: Cloudreach Cavalry gets +2/+2 and has flying as long as you control a Bird.

cards.name: Daru Mender
cards.text:
Morph {W} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Daru Mender is turned face up, regenerate target creature.

rulings.text: The trigger occurs when you use the Morph ability to turn the card face up, or when an effect turns it face up. It will not trigger on being revealed or on leaving the battlefield.

Morph {W} (You may play this face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)

Provoke (Whenever this creature attacks, you may have target creature defending player controls untap and block it if able.)

cards.name: Essence Sliver
cards.text: Whenever a Sliver deals damage, its controller gains that much life.
cards.flavor: The slivers would survive, even at the expense of every other creature on Otaria.

rulings.text: You only gain the life when the triggered ability resolves. If you are reduced to zero life before the ability resolves, you will lose before gaining the life.

Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn't provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it's no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.

cards.originalText: Whenever a Sliver deals damage, its controller gains that much life.

cards.name: Gempalm Avenger
cards.text:
Cycling {2}{W} ({2}{W}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Gempalm Avenger, Soldier creatures get +1/+1 and gain first strike until end of turn.

rulings.text: Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

When you cycle this card, first the cycling ability goes on the stack, then the triggered ability goes on the stack on top of it. The triggered ability will resolve before you draw a card from the cycling ability.

The cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. If the triggered ability doesn't resolve (due to being countered with Stifle, for example, or if all its targets have become illegal), the cycling ability will still resolve and you'll draw a card.

cards.originalText:
Cycling {2}{W} ({2}{W}, Discard this card from your hand: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Gempalm Avenger, all Soldiers get +1/+1 and gain first strike until end of turn.

cards.originalText: Noncreature spells cost {1} more to play.

cards.name: Planar Guide
cards.text: {3}{W}, Exile Planar Guide: Exile all creatures. At the beginning of the next end step, return those cards to the battlefield under their owners' control.
cards.flavor: "Every moment has its own savior."

rulings.text: All "enters the battlefield" abilities trigger as normal.
Creatures that were face down return to the battlefield face up.
If the ability is activated during the End step, then the creatures do not return until the End step of the following turn.

When the creatures leave the battlefield, all Auras on them go to their owners' graveyards, any counters on them are removed, and effects on them end. Token creatures do not return to the battlefield.

cards.originalText: {3}{W}, Remove Planar Guide from the game: Remove all creatures from the game. At end of turn, return those cards to play under their owners' control.

cards.name: Plated Sliver
cards.text: All Sliver creatures get +0/+1.
cards.flavor: Overcoming extinction has only made the slivers more determined to live.

rulings.text: Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn't provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it's no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.

All Slivers have protection from the chosen color.

rulings.text: Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn't provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it's no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.

rulings.text: If you use this ability on the same creature more than once, the cost is cumulative.

cards.name: Windborn Muse
cards.text:
Flying
Creatures can't attack you unless their controller pays {2} for each creature they control that's attacking you.
cards.flavor:
"Her voice is justice, clear and relentless."
—Akroma, angelic avenger

rulings.text: If you have more than one of these on the battlefield, the cost is cumulative.
In the Two-Headed Giant format, you still only have to pay once per creature.
Unless some effect explicitly says otherwise, a creature that can't attack you can still attack a planeswalker you control.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Creatures can't attack you unless their controller pays {2} for each creature attacking you. (This cost is paid as attackers are declared.)

cards.flavor: Pathmages can open doors that aren't even there.

cards.name: Chromeshell Crab
cards.text:
Morph {4}{U} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Chromeshell Crab is turned face up, you may exchange control of target creature you control and target creature an opponent controls.

rulings.text: You choose the two target creatures when the triggered ability is put onto the stack. You do not have to choose Chromeshell Crab. You choose whether or not to do the exchange on resolution.
The exchange fails if either target is not still on the battlefield at that time.
The exchange fails if either you no longer control your creature or the other creature is now controlled by you.
The creatures can't attack until you start a turn with them under your control. So you can't swap and then attack.
The trigger occurs when you use the Morph ability to turn the card face up, or when an effect turns it face up. It will not trigger on being revealed or on leaving the battlefield.

cards.originalText:
Morph {4}{U} (You may play this face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Chromeshell Crab is turned face up, you may exchange control of target creature you control and target creature an opponent controls.

cards.name: Fugitive Wizard
cards.flavor: Many wizards came to the Riptide Project hoping to return home with answers. Most, however, wouldn't return home at all.

cards.text:

When you cycle Gempalm Sorcerer, Wizard creatures gain flying until end of turn.

rulings.text: Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

When you cycle this card, first the cycling ability goes on the stack, then the triggered ability goes on the stack on top of it. The triggered ability will resolve before you draw a card from the cycling ability.

The cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. If the triggered ability doesn't resolve (due to being countered with Stifle, for example, or if all its targets have become illegal), the cycling ability will still resolve and you'll draw a card.

cards.text: When Merchant of Secrets enters the battlefield, draw a card.
cards.flavor: To scrape out a living in Aphetto, wizards are reduced to selling rumors, lies, forgeries, or—if they get desperate enough—the truth.
cards.originalText: When Merchant of Secrets comes into play, draw a card.

cards.name: Mistform Seaswift
cards.text:
Flying
{1}: Mistform Seaswift becomes the creature type of your choice until end of turn.
Morph {1}{U} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
cards.originalText:
Flying
{1}: Mistform Seaswift's type becomes the creature type of your choice until end of turn.
Morph {1}{U} (You may play this face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)

cards.name: Mistform Sliver
cards.text: All Slivers have "{1}: This permanent becomes the creature type of your choice in addition to its other types until end of turn."
cards.flavor: Taking the form of a junior researcher, the first sliver slipped out of Riptide.

rulings.text: Unlike most type changing effects, this one adds a creature type instead of replacing existing creature types.

Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn't provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it's no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.

cards.originalText: All Slivers have "{1}: This creature's type becomes the creature type of your choice in addition to its other types until end of turn."

cards.name: Mistform Ultimus
cards.text: Mistform Ultimus is every creature type (even if this card isn't on the battlefield).
cards.flavor: It may wear your face, but its mind is its own.

rulings.text: The type "Illusion" is printed on the card's type line purely for flavor. The Ultimus has every other creature type as well.
Like any creature, if Mistform Ultimus becomes another type as the result of a spell or ability, it will lose all its other creature types.
Mistform Ultimus has all creature types even if an effect removes its ability. Type-changing static abilities will apply in layer 4 before effects such as Sudden Spoiling's remove them in layer 6.

cards.originalText:
Mistform Ultimus is every creature type (even if this card isn't in play).
Mistform Ultimus may attack as though it weren't a Wall.

cards.name: Mistform Wakecaster
cards.text:
Flying
{1}: Mistform Wakecaster becomes the creature type of your choice until end of turn.
{2}{U}{U}, {T}: Choose a creature type. Each creature you control becomes that type until end of turn.
cards.originalText:
Flying
{1}: Mistform Wakecaster's type becomes the creature type of your choice until end of turn.
{2}{U}{U}, {T}: Choose a creature type. The type of each creature you control becomes that type until end of turn.

cards.name: Primoc Escapee
cards.text:
Flying
Cycling {2} ({2}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
cards.flavor: Though a completely artificial species, primocs are a natural fit for the skies of Otaria.

rulings.text: Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Cycling {2} ({2}, Discard this card from your hand: Draw a card.)

cards.name: Riptide Director
cards.text: {2}{U}{U}, {T}: Draw a card for each Wizard you control.
cards.flavor: Those who lead others to wisdom become the wisest themselves.
cards.originalText: {2}{U}{U}, {T}: Draw a card for each Wizard you control.

cards.name: Riptide Mangler
cards.text: {1}{U}: Change Riptide Mangler's base power to target creature's power. (This effect lasts indefinitely.)
cards.flavor: It wants you to be its chum.

rulings.text: The activated ability overwrites all previous effects that set Riptide Mangler's base power to specific a value (such as previous activations of the ability). Other effects that set its base power that start to apply after Riptide Mangler's ability resolves will overwrite this effect.

Effects that modify Riptide Mangler's power, such as the effect of Giant Growth or Glorious Anthem, will apply to Riptide Mangler no matter when they started applying. The same is true for counters that affect Riptide Mangler's power and effects that switch its power and toughness.

cards.originalText: {1}{U}: Change Riptide Mangler's power to target creature's power. (It doesn't change back at end of turn.)

cards.name: Shifting Sliver
cards.text: Slivers can't be blocked except by Slivers.
cards.flavor: Once the last few slivers the Riptide Project controlled were dead, there was nothing to keep the island from being completely overrun.

rulings.text: Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn't provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it's no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.

cards.originalText: Slivers can't be blocked except by Slivers.

cards.name: Synapse Sliver
cards.text: Whenever a Sliver deals combat damage to a player, its controller may draw a card.
cards.flavor:
"Species XR17 feeds upon the mental energies of its victims. This explains why the goblins remain unaffected."
—Riptide Project researcher

rulings.text: Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn't provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it's no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.

cards.originalText: Whenever a Sliver deals combat damage to a player, its controller may draw a card.

cards.name: Voidmage Apprentice
cards.text:
Morph {2}{U}{U} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Voidmage Apprentice is turned face up, counter target spell.

rulings.text: The trigger occurs when you use the Morph ability to turn the card face up, or when an effect turns it face up. It will not trigger on being revealed or on leaving the battlefield.

If a spell with split second is on the stack, you can still respond by turning this creature face up and targeting that spell with the trigger. This is because split second only stops players from casting spells or activating abilities, while turning a creature face up is a special action.

cards.name: Warped Researcher
cards.text: Whenever a player cycles a card, Warped Researcher gains flying and shroud until end of turn. (It can't be the target of spells or abilities.)
cards.flavor: New insights yield new senses.

rulings.text: On your turn, an opponent can cycle a card that has a cycling triggered ability and target this card with that ability. This works on your turn because your triggered abilities go on the stack first, so your opponent's ability will resolve before yours. This situation is reversed on your opponent's turn.

cards.originalText: Whenever a player cycles a card, Warped Researcher gains flying until end of turn and can't be the target of spells or abilities this turn.

cards.name: Weaver of Lies
cards.text:

When Weaver of Lies is turned face up, turn any number of target creatures with morph abilities other than Weaver of Lies face down.

rulings.text: The trigger occurs when you use the Morph ability to turn the card face up, or when an effect turns it face up. It will not trigger on being revealed or on leaving the battlefield.

cards.name: Willbender
cards.text:
Morph {1}{U} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Willbender is turned face up, change the target of target spell or ability with a single target.

rulings.text: The trigger occurs when you use the Morph ability to turn the card face up, or when an effect turns it face up. It will not trigger on being revealed or on leaving the battlefield.

If a spell with split second is on the stack, you can still respond by turning this creature face up and targeting that spell with the trigger. This is because split second only stops players from casting spells or activating abilities, while turning a creature face up is a special action.

You don't choose the new target for the spell until Willbender's triggered ability resolves. You must change the target if possible. However, you can't change the target to an illegal target. If there are no legal targets to choose from, the target isn't changed. It doesn't matter if the original target of that spell has somehow become illegal itself.
If a spell or ability targets multiple things, you can't target it with Willbender's triggered ability, even if all but one of those targets have become illegal.
If a spell or ability targets the same player or object multiple times, you can't target it with Willbender's ability.

cards.originalText:
Morph {1}{U} (You may play this face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Willbender is turned face up, change the target of target spell or ability with a single target.

cards.text:

When Bane of the Living is turned face up, all creatures get -X/-X until end of turn.

rulings.text: The trigger occurs when you use the Morph ability to turn the card face up, or when an effect turns it face up. It will not trigger on being revealed or on leaving the battlefield.
The X in the ability has the same value as the X paid in the Morph ability. This is pretty easy to derive since there is no other source of X.

rulings.text: You do not have to find a Zombie card or swamp card if you do not want to, even if you have them in your library.

cards.name: Crypt Sliver
cards.text: All Slivers have "{T}: Regenerate target Sliver."
cards.flavor:
"Death couldn't contain the slivers. What made us think we could?"
—Riptide Project researcher

rulings.text: Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn't provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it's no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.

cards.originalText: All Slivers have "{T}: Regenerate target Sliver."

cards.name: Dark Supplicant

cards.flavor: Cabal clerics serve two masters: their patriarch and their god.

rulings.text: You can choose which and how many of the three zones (graveyard, hand, and library) you want to search.
You only shuffle your library if you choose to search it.

cards.originalText: {T}, Sacrifice three Clerics: Search your graveyard, hand, and/or library for a card named Scion of Darkness and put it into play. If you search your library this way, shuffle it.

cards.name: Embalmed Brawler
cards.text:
Amplify 1 (As this creature enters the battlefield, put a +1/+1 counter on it for each Zombie card you reveal in your hand.)
Whenever Embalmed Brawler attacks or blocks, you lose 1 life for each +1/+1 counter on it.
cards.originalText:
Amplify 1 (As this card comes into play, put a +1/+1 counter on it for each Zombie card you reveal in your hand.)
Whenever Embalmed Brawler attacks or blocks, you lose 1 life for each +1/+1 counter on it.

cards.name: Gempalm Polluter
cards.text:
Cycling {B}{B} ({B}{B}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Gempalm Polluter, you may have target player lose life equal to the number of Zombies on the battlefield.

rulings.text: Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

When you cycle this card, first the cycling ability goes on the stack, then the triggered ability goes on the stack on top of it. The triggered ability will resolve before you draw a card from the cycling ability.

The cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. If the triggered ability doesn't resolve (due to being countered with Stifle, for example, or if all its targets have become illegal), the cycling ability will still resolve and you'll draw a card.
You can cycle this card even if there are no targets for the triggered ability. That's because the cycling ability itself has no targets.

cards.originalText:
Cycling {B}{B} ({B}{B}, Discard this card from your hand: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Gempalm Polluter, you may have target player lose 1 life for each Zombie in play.

rulings.text: It is only considered "cast from your hand" if you cast it as a spell from your hand. Putting it onto the battlefield from your hand using a spell or ability will cause you to lose the game.
